text.p: - The arrest of a CIA station chief on charges of selling secrets to Moscow is a new twist in the war between intelligence services.
- Belarus is waiting for President Alexander Lukashenko's new steps with alarm.
- Will Balkarian nationalists' claims for independence turn the region into another "hot spot" in Russia?
- Russian officials believe the IMF loan will be granted by January next year despite Russia's budget problems.
- Truce in Belarus seems very fragile and if mass disorder continues President Lukashenko might dissolve parliament and impose direct presidential rule.
- President Boris Yeltsin has started taking his powers back, telling officials to get ready to account for their actions during his heart surgery.
- A new Moscow spy in the CIA is an effective response to the U.S. failure to charge former Russian spy Vladimir Galkin.
- President Yeltsin and Premier Chernomyrdin expressed concern over the Belarus confrontation during their first meeting after president's heart surgery.
- Russians are only slowly changing their attitude towards Germans, despite more open contacts between the two states, says an independent survey.
- There still remains a chance that a "fire" won't start in Belarus.
- We should not make unilateral concessions to NATO. They have never done that towards Russia and have never cared for our interests.
- President Lukashenko is clearly preparing the ground for more decisive action.
- The Moscow administration has banned the sale of vodka and other strong drinks close to schools and hospitals.
